The confinement effect of the boron oxide layer has attracted significant attention in the field of heterogeneous catalysis. In this study, we introduce a strategically designed Pd@boron oxide-boron nitride hybrid (Pd@BOₓ/BN) catalyst, synthesized via pyrolysis, impregnation, reduction, and water treatment processes, for catalyzing the Heck reaction. Structural analyses reveal highly dispersed Pd nanoparticles encapsulated by tunable BOₓ layers, with phase transitions (NH4B5O8 → H3BO3 → BOₓ) occurring during hydrogen reduction. Increasing the reduction temperature from 450 °C to 700 °C resulted in the formation of thicker BOₓ layers, while water treatment partially removed the surface BOₓ. The post-water treatment catalyst (Pd@BOₓ/BN-R700-W) exhibited activity 5.8 and 17.5 times higher than those of Pd@BOₓ/BN-R600 and untreated Pd@BOₓ/BN-R700 in the Heck reaction, respectively. This enhanced activity is attributed to the optimized BOₓ layer thickness and confinement effects. Furthermore, comprehensive evaluations of the substrate scope demonstrated that Pd@BOₓ/BN-R700-W exhibited superior catalytic activity compared to other catalysts. This is accompanied by notable stability and reusability, as evidenced by a yield retention exceeding 93 % after fourteen cycles and minimal palladium leaching of 0.13 %. This study underscores the efficacy of BOₓ layers confinement engineering as a robust approach for developing durable and highly efficient catalysts in Heck coupling reactions. Homogeneous palladium complexes including Pd(OAc)₂ [3,4] and Pd(PPh₃)₄ [5,6] have demonstrated efficacy in conventional Heck coupling reactions. However, they face significant challenges related to separation, metal leaching, recyclability, and long-term stability [7,8]. In response, heterogeneous catalysis has emerged as a promising alternative, employing supports such as metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) [9,10], carbon nanotubes [11–14], silica [15], and others [16,17] to stabilize palladium nanoparticles, thereby improving reusability while maintaining catalytic activity. Nonetheless, the aggregation of Pd nanoparticles during Heck reactions frequently results in catalyst deactivation, necessitating the development of alternative strategies to address this critical issue [18–20]. Recent research has concentrated on engineering high-performance heterogeneous Pd catalysts, such as Pd@MOF-APBA [21], where N,N'-bidentate APBA ligands effectively prevent nanoparticle aggregation. This catalyst exhibited outstanding catalytic performance in Heck reactions, achieving a high turnover numbers (TON) exceeding 95,000, with reduced metal leaching (4.8 ppm) and sustained activity over four recycling cycles. Despite significant advancements in heterogeneous Heck catalysis, the ongoing challenge of palladium nanoparticle aggregation under stringent reaction conditions remains, highlighting the necessity for advanced stabilization strategies to maintain nanoparticle dispersion and enhance catalytic performance. Hexagonal boron nitride (h-BN), commonly referred to as "white graphene," is characterized by alternating boron and nitrogen atoms configured in a layered honeycomb lattice, offering distinct advantages for catalytic applications [22,23]. This material exhibits a combination of strong in-plane covalent B-N bonds and interlayer van der Waals interactions, facilitating the creation of a robust and tunable support framework. Recent studies have demonstrated that strong metal-support interactions (SMSI) between h-BN supports and metal nanoparticles can significantly enhance catalytic stability and activity by altering the electronic structure of the metal and generating interfacial active sites [24–27]. Notably, the formation of boron oxide (BOx) layers on metal surfaces has been shown to promote catalytic reactions such as oxidative dehydrogenation and dry reforming of methane [28,29]. Additionally, the permeable nature of BOx layers allows reactant molecules to access the active surface, thereby improving reaction efficiency. Despite these promising developments, the exploration of new catalytic systems utilizing BOx layers encapsulated Pd catalysts to enhance catalytic activity and reusability in the Heck reaction remains limited. In this study, we developed catalysts with boron oxide (BOx) layers encapsulating Pd nanoparticles, denoted as Pd@BOx/BN structures. We systematically investigated the Heck reaction involving various substituted iodobenzenes with methyl acrylate and styrene using these catalysts. The Pd@BOx/BN-R700-W catalyst demonstrated significantly superior catalytic performance and excellent reusability compared to other representative catalysts in Heck reactions. These findings underscore the potential of BOx-encapsulated Pd catalysts as a promising platform for improving both catalytic efficiency and recyclability in Heck reactions. Furthermore, this work establishes a new paradigm for designing durable, high-performance heterogeneous catalysts through controlled BOx layers encapsulation engineering, with broad implications for sustainable pharmaceutical synthesis and fine chemical production. 2 Results and discussion 2.1 Synthesis and characterization of Pd@BOx/BN hybrid materials The Pd@boron oxide-boron nitride hybrid materials (Pd@BOx/BN) were successfully synthesized through a combined pyrolysis and wet impregnation approach, utilizing porous boron nitride (PBN) as the support matrix, followed by controlled thermal processing. Fig. 1 a provides a schematic representation of the synthesis procedure, which involves the impregnation of palladium chloride, subsequent air calcination at 200 °C, hydrogen reduction, and water treatment. As depicted in Fig. 1b, the XRD pattern reveals characteristic peaks corresponding to the (002) and (101) crystal planes of boron nitride at 2θ values of 25.7° and 42.4° (PDF#45-1171), respectively. Additionally, peaks at 2θ values of 25.1°, 26.3°, and 31.5° (PDF#31-0043) are attributed to the (202), (212), and (040) crystal planes of the NH4B5O8 crystal. TEM analysis, as shown in Fig. 1c, further confirms the high dispersion of palladium particles on the support. XPS analysis in Fig. 1d indicates the absence of zero-valence Pd species, likely due to the fact that PdCl2, when loaded onto the PBN surface and subjected to calcination in air at 200 °C, did not convert into metallic Pd. Hydrogen temperature-programmed reduction-mass spectrometry (H2-TPR-MS) analyses were performed on PdO/BOx/BN sample. Fig. 1e presents the H2-TPR spectrum of PdO/BOx/BN sample, revealing distinct temperature-dependent H2 consumption peaks that correspond to five reduction processes occurring at 258 °C, 349 °C, 414 °C, 676 °C, and 742 °C, respectively. Mass spectrometry data (Fig. 1f and g) indicate that the signals observed near 248 °C can be attributed to the formation of ammonia and water. The signals detected between 550–590 °C are associated with the production of CO and CH4, while those above 700 °C correspond to CO2 generation. Consequently, the PdCl2/PBN materials developed a PdO/BOx/BN hybrid structure following pretreatment in air at 200 °C. The relative surface elemental compositions of B 1 s, C 1 s, N 1 s, O 1 s, Pd 3d are detailed in Tables S1 and S2. To investigate the structural changes of the Pd@BO x /BN-RT catalysts during the reduction process, we characterized their textural properties of the Pd@BO x /BN-RT using X-ray diffraction (XRD), scanning electron microscopy (SEM), and transmission electron microscopy (TEM) analyses (Figs. 2 and S1–S4). The XRD analysis identified the presence of weak characteristic peaks associated with palladium, indicating that the palladium nanoparticles were either highly dispersed or encapsulated by H3BO3 and NH4B5O8 species (Fig. 2a). In the Pd@BOx/BN-R450 and Pd@BOx/BN-R600 catalysts, characteristic peaks corresponding to the (202) plane of NH4B5O8 were observed. Additionally, a characteristic peak corresponding to the (002) plane of boric acid (H3BO3) was detected in the XRD spectrum of Pd@BOx/BN-R600. Upon increasing the reduction temperature to 700 °C (Pd@BOx/BN-R700), the characteristic peaks of NH4B5O8 disappeared, and only those corresponding to the H3BO3 or BOx were observed in the XRD spectrum of the sample. These XRD results suggest that phase transformations occurred on the surface of Pd@BOx/BN during the reduction process, with BOx emerging as the predominant surface phase following reduction. The combined findings from XRD and H2-TPR analyses indicate a phase transition sequence (NH4B5O8 to H3BO3 and to BOx) within the sample during hydrogen reduction. The SEM images further revealed that an increase in the reduction temperature resulted in enhanced crystallinity of the Pd@BOx/BN-RT catalysts (Fig. S1). TEM was utilized to characterize the synthesized Pd NPs supported on Pd@BO x /BN-R450, Pd@BO x /BN-R600, and Pd@BO x /BN-R700 catalysts (Figs. 2b–d and S2-S4). The TEM images reveal that the majority of the Pd NPs exhibit an ellipsoidal morphology, as depicted in Fig. 2b–d A comprehensive particle analysis, conducted on multiple TEM images from various regions of these catalysts, confirmed that the Pd NPs predominantly have mean diameters of 4.80 nm for Pd@BO x /BN-R450, 4.52 nm for Pd@BO x /BN-R600, and 4.59 nm for Pd@BO x /BN-R700 catalyst, respectively. Notably, an increase in the reduction temperature did not lead to a significant enlargement in the size of Pd NPs. A novel and intriguing observation is that the in-situ synthesized Pd@BO x /BN-R600 and Pd@BO x /BN-R700 are encapsulated with a minimal number of BOx layers (Figs. S2 and S3), unlike the Pd@BO x /BN-R450 catalyst, which lacks such encapsulation. Furthermore, as the reduction temperature increased, the number of BOx layers in Pd@BO x /BN-R700 surpassed that in Pd@BOx/BN-R600. With an increase in reduction temperature, a significant rise in the number of BO x layers was observed in Pd@BO x /BN-R700 compared to the Pd@BO x /BN-R600, indicating a temperature-dependent enhancement in layer integration. Crystallographic analysis, as illustrated in Figs. S2 and S3, revealed lattice spacing for palladium at 0.213 nm and 0.238 nm, while the boron oxide (BO x ) layers extended to 0.334 nm and 0.346 nm. This observation clearly indicated the presence of BO x layers enveloping the active palladium center, suggesting a potential structural configuration that may influence catalytic performance. STEM and line-EDS analyses confirmed the presence of trace amounts of BO x layers on the surface of Pd@BO x /BN-R600 catalyst (Fig. S4b and c). The surface characteristics of these catalysts were further examined using X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), as detailed in Fig. 3 . The spectra distinctly revealed characteristic peaks corresponding to palladium (Pd), boron (B), nitrogen (N), and oxygen (O). The N 1 s XPS spectrum of the Pd catalyst exhibited peaks at 398.3 eV and 400.1 eV, attributable to B-N bonds and other nitrogen species. Simultaneously, the B 1 s XPS spectrum exhibited peaks at 190.7 eV, 192.3 eV, and 193.6 eV, which correspond to B-N, B-OH, and BO x species, respectively. Upon examining the O 1 s XPS spectrum, a notable increase in the intensity of the BO x peaks was observed with the elevation of the reduction temperature, suggesting a correlation between the boron oxide layer content and the reduction conditions. These findings confirmed the presence of boron oxide in the Pd@BOx/BN-R450, Pd@BOx/BN-R600, and Pd@BOx/BN-R700 catalysts. The Pd 3d XPS spectrum was deconvoluted into three distinct peaks, with a principal peak at 335 eV in the Pd@BOx/BN-R450, Pd@BOx/BN-R600, and Pd@BOx/BN-R700 catalysts. This observation indicates the coexistence of supported Pd (0) species, as illustrated in Fig. 2b The binding energy of Pd 3d in the catalysts was measured at 336.4 eV, indicative of oxidized Pd (II) species. Peaks above 338.3 eV in the Pd 3d spectrum corroborate the formation of Pd (IV) complexes. Therefore, the encapsulation of Pd species by boron oxide (BO x ) layers may potentially influence the catalyst's activity and stability in Heck reaction. 2.2 Investigation the heck reaction performance over Pd@BOx/BN hybrid catalysts To investigate the effect of reduction temperature on the BO x layers encapsulated Pd particles, the catalytic performance of PdO/BO x /BN and Pd@BO x /BN-RT catalysts were assessed in the Heck reaction between iodobenzene (IB) and methyl acrylate (MA), as depicted in Fig. 4 a. The reaction was conducted using 10 mg of each catalyst in 10 mL of dimethylformamide (DMF) containing IB (5 mmol) and MA (7.5 mmol) under atmospheric pressure. The conversion of IB over Pd@BO x /BN-R600 catalyst reached 0.33 mol·L−1·min−1 within 60 min at 100 °C, outperforming the Pd@BO x /BN-R450 catalyst (0.05 mol·L−1·min−1) and Pd@BO x /BN-R700 (0.065 mol·L−1·min−1). The PdO/BO x /BN catalyst did not catalyze the Heck reaction during the initial three hours. As the reduction temperature increased, the reaction rate initially increased and then decreased. This trend suggests that an optimal thickness of boron oxide layers enhances the reaction, whereas either excessive or insufficient thickness impedes it. A control experiment using pure NC support showed no conversion, indicating the necessity of Pd species for the Heck reaction. The conversion of IB over the Pd@BO x /BN-R600 catalyst (30 mg) reached up to 14 % within 20 min at 100 °C, surpassing the performance of the Pd@BO x /BN-R600 catalyst (10 mg, 60 min with conversion 9.2 %), as illustrated in Fig. 4b The average turnover frequency (ATOF) of Pd@BO x /BN-R600 catalyst (30 mg) is 776 h−1, while the ATOF for Pd@BO x /BN-R600 catalyst (10 mg) is 498 h−1. The size distribution of these catalysts was found to be similar (Fig. 2), suggesting that Pd@BOx/BN-R450, Pd@BOx/BN-R600, and Pd@BOx/BN-R700 likely exhibit comparable dispersion of Pd nanoparticles. A positive correlation is observed between the reaction rate of the Heck reaction and the surface concentration of zero-valent palladium (Fig. 4c). The catalytic activity of the Heck reaction increases with a higher content of Pd (0) species. Time-conversion plots for the Heck reaction of IB and MA were analyzed at various temperatures, as shown in Fig. 4d The reaction of IB over Pd@BO x /BN-R600 achieved a conversion rate of 0.33 mol·L−1·min−1 within 60 min at 100 °C, outperforming the conversion rates of 0.13 mol·L−1·min−1 within 60 min at 90 °C and 0.055 mol·L−1·min−1 within 60 min at 80 °C. These comparisons indicate that the surface boron oxide layers significantly accelerate the Heck reaction. To further elucidate the impact of boron oxide layer thickness on the Heck reaction, we employed a catalyst with relatively lower activity, which reduction at 700 °C (Pd@BOx/BN-R700) and was characterized by a thicker boron oxide layer (Fig. S2). This surface of this catalyst was partially stripped of its boron oxide layer through water treatment (Figs. S6 and S7). STEM analysis revealed a reduction in the number of boron oxide layers on the catalyst surface post-water treatment (Pd@BOx/BN-R700-W). Furthermore, line-EDS data corroborated the thinning of the boron oxide layers on the catalyst surface following water treatment (Fig. S7). The results form BET (Fig. S8), XPS (Fig. S9), and XRD (Fig. S10) analyses corroborate the finding that water treatment results in a reduction of boron oxide layers on the catalyst surface. We investigated the time-conversion plots for the Heck reaction of IB and MA using these catalysts at various temperatures (Fig. 5 c and d and S11). Notably, the reaction of IB over Pd@BOx/BN-R700-W achieved an initial rate of 1.14 mol·L−1·min−1 within 10 min, significantly surpassing the 0.065 mol·L−1·min−1 rate observed within 60 min for the Pd@BOx/BN-R700 catalyst. These findings underscore the substantial influence of boron oxide layer thickness on the activity of the Heck reaction, indicating that palladium-based catalysts with an optimized boron oxide layers can enhance the reaction rate. To investigate the influence of the boron oxide layers on the stability and reusability of catalysts, we conducted thermal filtration and reusability experiments on the Pd@BOx/BN-R600 and Pd@BOx/BN-R700-W catalysts (Figs. 6 and S12). Notably, the Pd@BOx/BN-R600 catalyst yielded only 20 % of methyl cinnamate following a 30-minute thermal filtration test (Fig. S12a). The conversion of the Heck reaction decreased from 99 % in the initial use to 81 % in the seventh cycle, suggesting a certain degree of stability and reusability on Pd@BOx/BN-R600 catalyst, albeit suboptimal. By modifying the thickness of the boron oxide layers, the catalytic activity was significantly enhanced (Fig. S11). Consequently, we explored whether the stability of the catalyst could also be improved by modulating the boron oxide layers thickness. In this context, we evaluated the stability of the Pd@BOx/BN-R700-W catalyst, as illustrated in Fig. 6. Remarkably, after 14 cycles of reuse, the reaction conversion remained high at 93 %, with the catalyst demonstrating an average palladium leaching of only 0.13 %. The findings indicate that by precisely adjusting the thickness of the boron oxide layer on the catalyst surface through reduction and water treatment, the activity and stability of the Pd@BOx/BN-R700-W catalyst can be significantly improved. Post-reaction characterization of the spent catalyst was conducted using electron microscopy, revealing a slight increase in the size of the palladium particles. Line scanning analyses demonstrated that the spent catalyst possessed only a few layers of boron oxide on the outer surface of the palladium particles. This thin boron oxide layer enhances the catalyst's activity and stability via a confinement effect. Consequently, it can be inferred that Pd@BOx/BN-R700-W exhibits superior catalytic activity compared to Pd@BOx/BN-R700, thereby confirming that the confinement effect can accelerate chemical reactions and enhance both catalyst activity and stability. Subsequently, the confinement effects of Pd@BOx/BN-R700-W and Pd@BOx/BN-R700 catalysts were investigated using 4-substituted IBs and MA. The results demonstrated that Pd@BOx/BN-R700-W exhibited higher activity than Pd@BOx/BN-R700 during the Heck reaction for the majority of the substrates, as illustrated in Figs. 7 a–f and S15. The average turnover frequency (ATOF) value for para-fluorine-substituted IB with MA over Pd@BOx/BN-R700-W was 1283 h−1, in contrast to a significantly lower value of 474 h−1 observed with the Pd@BOx/BN-R700 (Fig. S15, p-F-IB). Consequently, the ATOF value for para-F-IB and MA over Pd@BOx/BN-R700-W was 2.7 times higher than that over Pd@BOx/BN-R700. As depicted in Fig. 7d, the reaction conversion for IB and MA over Pd@BOx/BN-R700-W was also much higher than that over Pd@BOx/BN-R700. Specifically, the ATOF value for IB and MA over Pd@BOx/BN-R700-W was 4196 h−1, whereas it was only 240 h−1 over Pd@BOx/BN-R700, indicating a 17.5-fold increase. The average TOF values for various para-substituted IBs and MA are shown in Fig. S11. The ATOF values for these substrates, namely, p-F (Fig. 7(a)), p-Cl (Fig. 7(b)), p-Br (Fig. 7(c)), p-H (Fig. 7(d)), p-CH3 (Fig. 7(e)), and, p–OCH3 (Fig. 7(f))) over Pd@BOx/BN-R700W were 1283, 1608, 1528, 4196, 2034, and 2128 h−1, respectively. In contrast, their ATOF values over Pd@BOx/BN-R700 were 474, 569, 498, 240, 298, and 307 h−1, respectively. Thus, the ATOF values over Pd@BOx/BN-R700-W were 2.7, 2.8, 3.1, 17.5, 6.8, and 6.9 times higher, than those over Pd@BOx/BN-R700, respectively. To evaluate the scope of the confinement effect of boron oxide layers in Pd@BOx/BN-R700-W and Pd@BOx/BN-R700 catalysts during the Heck reaction of between various 4-substituted IBs and styrene, the catalytic performances of the two catalysts were systematically investigated. The findings, presented in Figs. 8 and S16, reveal that the ATOF value for the reaction of para-F-IB and styrene over Pd@BOx/BN-R700-W was 694 h−1, surpassing the 498 h−1 observed for Pd@BOx/BN-R700. The ATOF values for the Heck reaction over Pd@BOx/BN-R700-W and Pd@BOx/BN-R700 followed the sequence: para-Cl (819 and 340 h−1, respectively), para-Br (742 and 293 h−1, respectively), para-H (363 and 58 h−1, respectively), para–OCH3 (604 and 293 h−1, respectively), and para-CH3 (618 and 277 h−1, respectively). These results demonstrated that Pd@BOx/BN-R700-W exhibits superior performance compared to Pd@BOx/BN-R700 in the Heck reaction of the para-substituted IBs and styrene. The observed differences in the catalytic performances between Pd@BOx/BN-R700-W and Pd@BOx/BN-R700 can likely be attributed to variations in their electronic properties and steric hindrance effects. Additionally, we have substantiated the efficacy of Pd@BOx/BN-R700-W in catalyzing the Heck reaction across a broad range of substrates, including aromatic bromides with alkenes, as detailed in Table S3. Moreover, the catalytic performance of Pd@BOx/BN-R700-W and Pd@BOx/BN-R700 was further validated in other Pd-based reactions, such as the hydrogenation of nitrobenzene and benzaldehyde, as well as the Ullmann reaction, as illustrated in Fig. S17. Some related works have been cited to further demonstrated that Pd@BOx/BN-R700-W has excellent performance and reusability in Heck reaction, as displayed in Table 1 . Furthermore, all the results indicated that the confinement of the palladium nanoparticles within the optimal boron oxide layers accelerated the Heck reaction. 3 Conclusion In conclusion, we have developed a straightforward synthesis method utilizing a calcination-reduction-leaching strategy to immobilize Pd nanoparticles within boron oxide layers, thereby enabling the controlled preparation of Pd@BOₓ/BN hybrid catalysts. A range of characterization techniques, including Transmission Electron Microscopy (TEM) and X-ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy (XPS) were employed to verify that the Pd nanoparticles were highly dispersed on the boron nitride (BN) support, with the average particle size remaining relatively constant despite variations in reduction temperature (Pd@BOx/BN-R450: 4.80 nm, Pd@BOx/BN-R600: 4.52 nm, Pd@BOx/BN-R700: 4.59 nm, and Pd@BOx/BN-R700-W: 4.44 nm). TEM and XPS analyses further confirmed the presence of a few layers of boron oxide-encapsulated palladium nanoparticles in the Pd@BOₓ/BN-R600, Pd@BOₓ/BN-R700 and Pd@BOₓ/BN-700-W catalysts. We conducted a systematic evaluation of the influence of boron oxide layers on the catalytic performance in Heck reactions, revealing that the Pd@BOₓ/BN-R600 catalyst exhibited the highest initial reaction rate (0.33 mol L−1·min−1), which was significantly higher than thos of Pd@BOₓ/BN-R450 (0.05 mol L−1·min−1) and Pd@BOₓ/BN-R700 (0.065 mol L−1·min−1). The enhanced catalytic activity can be attributed to the interaction between the palladium particles and boron oxide layers. Notably, Pd@BOₓ/BN-R700-W, exhibited exceptional activity and superior stability. The activity of Pd@BOₓ/BN-R700-W outperformed other Pd@BOₓ/BN-R700 and Pd@BOₓ/BN-R600 catalysts in Heck reactions. Specifically, the initial reaction for IB with MA in Pd@BOₓ/BN-R700-W was 1.14 mol L−1·min−1, which is markedly higher than the rates achieved with Pd@BOₓ/BN-R700 (0.065 mol L−1·min−1) and Pd@BOₓ/BN-R600 (0.33 mol L−1·min−1), respectivily. The TOF value for Pd@BOₓ/BN-R700-W was 4916 h−1, approximately 17.5 times higher than that of the Pd@BOₓ/BN-R700 catalyst in the Heck reaction. Additionally, extensive substrate scope studies revealed that the Pd@BOₓ/BN-R700-W exhibited enhanced catalytic activity compared to Pd@BOₓ/BN-R700, maintaining remarkable stability even after 14 cycles of reuse, with a consistent yield of 93 % and a minimal palladium loss of 0.13 %. This work successfully demonstrates the dynamic encapsulation of palladium particles via the modulation of the boron oxide layers, underscoring the significant potential of BOₓ layers-encapsulated palladium catalysts for large-scale applications in Heck reactions. coredata.dc:description: The confinement effect of the boron oxide layer has attracted significant attention in the field of heterogeneous catalysis. In this study, we introduce a strategically designed Pd@boron oxide-boron nitride hybrid (Pd@BOₓ/BN) catalyst, synthesized via pyrolysis, impregnation, reduction, and water treatment processes, for catalyzing the Heck reaction. Structural analyses reveal highly dispersed Pd nanoparticles encapsulated by tunable BOₓ layers, with phase transitions (NH4B5O8 → H3BO3 → BOₓ) occurring during hydrogen reduction. Increasing the reduction temperature from 450 °C to 700 °C resulted in the formation of thicker BOₓ layers, while water treatment partially removed the surface BOₓ. The post-water treatment catalyst (Pd@BOₓ/BN-R700-W) exhibited activity 5.8 and 17.5 times higher than those of Pd@BOₓ/BN-R600 and untreated Pd@BOₓ/BN-R700 in the Heck reaction, respectively. This enhanced activity is attributed to the optimized BOₓ layer thickness and confinement effects. Furthermore, comprehensive evaluations of the substrate scope demonstrated that Pd@BOₓ/BN-R700-W exhibited superior catalytic activity compared to other catalysts. This is accompanied by notable stability and reusability, as evidenced by a yield retention exceeding 93 % after fourteen cycles and minimal palladium leaching of 0.13 %. This study underscores the efficacy of BOₓ layers confinement engineering as a robust approach for developing durable and highly efficient catalysts in Heck coupling reactions.
